comment: This idea Viktor uses is not new by any means. 7...a6!? has the idea of pushing to b5 and bringing the bishop out on b7. It's a solid line, which doesn't waste time as it may seem with the wing pawn advance. Why is that exactly? I thought we were taught that all unneeded wing pawn advances are a waste of time? However, tempo has a less binding effect in the closed game. This position is very closed. The kings don't "need" to get to safety immediately, the development of pieces quickly is not quite as important as staking out space with pawns in this type of game. Therefore, 4...a6 is a useful strategic move that doesn't lose tempo to any serious extent.
reasoning: The comment offers a counter-argument to the player's assessment, suggesting a more flexible approach to development.
